So, if he's kept 100 yards from a funeral, isn't that "trying to shut him up"? 

 
 Well, in this particular case, I'd say it's not shutting him so much as preventing him from causing a public nuisance to others in pursuit of their legitimate business. I think this is a borderline case, and moving him a few hundred yards away from a funeral -- and this applies only to military funerals if I recall -- is not really much of an infringement of his freedom of speech. Mourners have rights in public, too, and a funeral is often a mixed private and public event -- where you come down probably depends on whether you are thinking more of the mourners or the protesters.
 
 
Personally, I do think he should be shut up and he's pretty sick and evil, and his message serves no one except his overblown sense of self-importance; however, where does freedom of speech play in this? I really don't understand how far the constitutional law reaches into this situation.

 
 Constitutionally, speech hasn't been considered an absolute freedom -- no-one has the right to stand up anywhere and say anything they please at any time they fancy. Courts have allowed reasonable restrictions that try to balance freedom of public expression with freedom from public nuisance. I'll agree it's not an easy line to police in such a way that everyone is satisfied. For example, the so-called "free speech zones" at Bush's campaign appearances in 2004 seemed to me to go way over the line, and much further than anything done against Phelps.
 
 I tend to sit in a camp that doesn't support absolute free speech right on a knee jerk basis, but is very suspicious of any attempts to limit it. I think it's right to be suspicious of any anti-demonstration laws, and they do deserve extensive scrutiny. If a court were to strike down this law, I wouldn't mount the barricades in its defence, but at the same time, I don't regard it as particularly inhibiting to free speech. Phelps and his klan can still say everything they want to -- a couple of hundred yards away. Their presence will still be reported and registered, they just won't be able to confront a mourning family directly with their malevolence.
